item.title: How to get the current selected Xcode and list installed
item.description: Some tips & tricks on how to get the current selected Xcode and check for available local versions.

item.title: Multiple Xcode versions or Why `xcrun` is your friend
item.description: I recently spent a few hours helping a friend of mine investigate a weird issue in their Continuous Development infrastructure. Builds were failing with different fatal errors mostly related to SDK paths and .platform directory locations. At first sight, it was clear that something is wrong with the current selected Xcode, but all our initial attempts to catch the problem failed.

item.title: Grammarly iOS Keyboard - Unboxing
item.description: Grammarly is a lovely writing assistant. Twenty million people use the tool across the globe according to the statistics available on the site. I use it too. No complaints, it does its job quite well, and I am a happy user. The only thing that always worried me is the Grammarly iOS Keyboard. As an iOS engineer, I know how easily you can collect different data, sensitive information, and even do not ask users about the consent. So, let’s check what is inside the Grammarly iOS application.

item.title: Xcode invocation tool - xed
item.description: xed is a command-line tool that launches the Xcode application and opens the given documents (xcodeproj, xcworkspace, etc.), or opens a new document, optionally with the contents of standard input.

item.title: Dr. Anthony Fauci Cold Open - SNL
item.description: “Oh, Brad Pitt, of course” Dr. Anthony Fauci said.

item.title: About Bob Martin's talk - The Future of Programming (2016)
item.description: I am a bit late to the party, but still. Robert C. Martin, colloquially known as “Uncle Bob”, gave the exciting talk in May 2016 about the future of the programming. The usefulness of his words still stands, and it is a beautiful history lesson about software engineering, programming as a profession with remarks about Agile and possible future of the industry.

item.title: Emojis over time
item.description: How have Apple emojis evolved lately (iOS 13.0-13.3) and what is gender-neutral philosophy.

item.title: Note: Xcode 10.2, macOS Mojave 10.14.4, iOS 12.1 and other betas
item.description: Quick overview of the recent betas from Apple. iOS centric.

item.title: Swift Package Manager builds iOS frameworks (Updated. Xcode 10.2 Beta)
item.description: Swift Package Manager doesn’t work with iOS. Probably, that’s all you can say about the current state of SPM, but insomnia forced me to extend the answer to the following essay.
